SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVE QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name ... A. H. Mawby
2. Your address ... Hallworth, Sask.
3. Date ... March 14, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Cypress River, Manitoba
5. What was your father's name and occupation? George Mawby — Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) June - 1912
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.).

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To get land and make a home of my own.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). Through my uncles and I followed and settled in the Sisdale area.
1. Your full name: Mr. St. Maurt
2. Your address: Waller, Alberta
3. Date: March 16, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. What did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   June - 1912
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)
   Through my uncle and I followed and settled in the Hidale area.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They figured prosperity was ahead to stay with it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   With a party.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   By train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Sisdoe, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Sec. 16 - T. 41 - Range 15 W. 2nd.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   Never did anything else but farm.
21. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They figured prosperity was ahead to stay.

22. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

23. What means of transportation did you use?

By train.

24. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, weather conditions, experiences on the journey, accidents or other events, etc.)

25. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Medicine Hat.

26. Where did you settle or take up land?

Site 16 - 16 - 41 - Range 18 - W 2nd.

27. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

28. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Never did anything else but farm.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Osabelle Tucker - Nov. 14, 1922
   Hiodale, Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   Mother came up in 1914 and settled in the same district, also three brothers and a sister.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Had a sod roof shanty and when it rained for several days at a time the old dry place in the shanty was under the table which had a oilcloth on and I put sugar, flour, etc. under it to keep dry.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Yes, went twenty to thirty five miles to dances once every month, and closer dances once every week.
   There was no church till 1923 when our school was build.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Dorothy Tucker, Haskins, Mo., 1922.

21. Did anyone else come to Cashia County because of your recommendation? If so, please list them.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came first, tell us when they came and where they settled.

Mother came up in 1914 and settled in the same district also three brothers and a sister.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Had a sod roof shanty and when it rained for several days at a time the old dry place in the shanty was under the table which had a cloth on it and I put sugar, flour, etc. under it to keep dry.

24. How much did you travel about? In the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting relatives, etc.) How far? By what means of travel?

Geo. went twenty to thirty four miles to dance once every week, and closer dances once every month. No church till 1923 when our school was build.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   In 1928.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Chagresis, Saskatchewan - 18 miles by canoe.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Trade in Wablon 1920. C.P.R. Railroad came there in 1928. Then I traded at McHague.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Once a month.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Ever since roads were fit to travel on.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Ever since 1912 I purchased all clothing through mail order catalogues.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Closet telephone here is four miles from us.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes.
25. When was the first car used in your community?
   In 1928.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Chrysler.

27. Where was your trading centre? How far from your house?
   3½ miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Trade in Wainwright 1920; C.P.R. Railroad came thru in 1923; then I traded at Eric Hague.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Once a month.

30. When did people in your district first start going to town regularly?
   Our wives would be fit to travel on.

31. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what proportion of purchases made by mail order shows the pioneer period.
   Every article purchased all clothing.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   About telephone here to four miles from us.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

No

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Yes. No.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Organized School, Build school in 1923, and was on the School Board for 19 yrs, was one of the first signs on the Wheat Pool. Assisted driving organizer for United Farmers around.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

Was first in owning a combine.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

School Young School got its name thru one member who was on the School Board, which was their home town in Ontario. Year 1923. Wallwest P.O. got its name thru a herb which is found growing in this community in 1933. McKague got its name from people who lived there.
5. If you or some member of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Organized school. Built school in 1923.

One of the first signs on the school board. Also first in running a contest.

36. Did any important events occur during the period 1924-1930?

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in buying or doing something in the district mention it here. Giving data wherever possible, (such as name of the first automobile, company organizing the first telephone, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School district, Post Office, town, village, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any change in names since the first name was given, (5) reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Vernon School got its name from one member who was on the school board. Which was their home town in Ontario - year 1923.

Wallnut P.O. got its name from a field which is found growing in this community in 1933.

McKeague got its name from people who lived there.

Then it was solid brush and lots of water, you could not go any place until you cut out a road.

The change there has been in handling brush land from the old grub hoe and axe to modern machinery such as bull dozers and brush cutters.

Alf Mowbray
